title: Luke Chapter 18 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Luke chapter 18 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Luke Chapter 18 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Luke Chapter 18.

questions.question: What was the main lesson of the parable Jesus spoke in Luke 18:1?
options: Men ought always to pray and not faint
Men should seek riches
Men should judge others
Men should fast twice a week
questions.correctAnswer: Men ought always to pray and not faint
questions.explanation: Luke 18:1 teaches that men ought always to pray and not faint.

questions.question: In Luke 18:2, what kind of judge is described in the city?
options: A judge who feared not God nor regarded man
A righteous and just judge
A judge who was kind to widows
A judge who was very poor
questions.correctAnswer: A judge who feared not God nor regarded man
questions.explanation: Luke 18:2 describes a judge who feared not God nor regarded man.

questions.question: Who came to the judge asking for justice in Luke 18:3?
options: A widow
A Pharisee
A publican
A ruler
questions.correctAnswer: A widow
questions.explanation: Luke 18:3 states that a widow came to the judge asking to avenge her of her adversary.

questions.question: According to Luke 18:7, who will God avenge?
options: His own elect who cry to Him day and night
Those who are rich
The Pharisees
The rulers of the city
questions.correctAnswer: His own elect who cry to Him day and night
questions.explanation: Luke 18:7 says God will avenge His own elect who cry day and night unto Him.

questions.question: Who were the two men that went up to pray in the temple in Luke 18:10?
options: A Pharisee and a publican
A judge and a widow
Peter and John
A ruler and a soldier
questions.correctAnswer: A Pharisee and a publican
questions.explanation: Luke 18:10 tells of two men, a Pharisee and a publican, who went up into the temple to pray.

questions.question: What did the Pharisee thank God for in his prayer in Luke 18:11?
options: That he was not as other men
That he was wealthy
That he was a ruler
That he was poor
questions.correctAnswer: That he was not as other men
questions.explanation: Luke 18:11 records the Pharisee thanking God that he was not like other men.

questions.question: How did the publican pray in Luke 18:13?
options: He stood afar off, not lifting his eyes, and said, 'God be merciful to me a sinner.'
He thanked God for his righteousness
He boasted about his good deeds
He prayed for wealth
questions.correctAnswer: He stood afar off, not lifting his eyes, and said, 'God be merciful to me a sinner.'
questions.explanation: Luke 18:13 describes the publican humbly praying for mercy, not lifting his eyes to heaven.

questions.question: According to Jesus in Luke 18:14, who will be exalted?
options: He that humbleth himself
He that exalteth himself
The rich
The rulers
questions.correctAnswer: He that humbleth himself
questions.explanation: Luke 18:14 states that he who humbleth himself shall be exalted.

questions.question: What did Jesus say about children in Luke 18:16?
options: Suffer little children to come unto me, for of such is the kingdom of God
Children should be taught to fast
Children should be kept away from Jesus
Children should be silent
questions.correctAnswer: Suffer little children to come unto me, for of such is the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Luke 18:16 records Jesus inviting children to come to Him because the kingdom of God belongs to them.

questions.question: What commandment did Jesus mention to the ruler in Luke 18:20?
options: Do not commit adultery, Do not kill, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Honour thy father and thy mother
Love your neighbor as yourself
Keep the Sabbath holy
Do not worship idols
questions.correctAnswer: Do not commit adultery, Do not kill, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Honour thy father and thy mother
questions.explanation: Luke 18:20 lists these commandments as known by the ruler.

questions.question: What did Jesus say the rich man lacked in Luke 18:22?
options: He lacked one thing: to sell all that he had and give to the poor
He lacked wisdom
He lacked faith
He lacked prayer
questions.correctAnswer: He lacked one thing: to sell all that he had and give to the poor
questions.explanation: Luke 18:22 tells the rich man he lacked selling all he had and distributing to the poor.

questions.question: True or False: In Luke 18:25, Jesus said it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 18:25 uses the camel and needle's eye analogy about the difficulty for a rich man to enter God's kingdom.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 18:27, things impossible with men are impossible with God as well.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 18:27 states that things impossible with men are possible with God.

questions.question: True or False: In Luke 18:33, Jesus said He would rise again on the third day after being put to death.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 18:33 states that Jesus will rise again on the third day after His death.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Luke 18:41: 'Lord, that I may receive my ______.'
options: sight
faith
mercy
healing
questions.correctAnswer: sight
questions.explanation: Luke 18:41 records the blind man asking Jesus to restore his sight.

medium.title: Luke Chapter 18 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Luke Chapter 18 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged in prayer and feels like giving up. Based on Luke 18:1-8, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance in prayer?
options: Men ought always to pray and not to faint
God does not hear repeated prayers
Prayer is only necessary in times of crisis
Only public prayers are effective
questions.correctAnswer: Men ought always to pray and not to faint
questions.explanation: Luke 18:1 instructs that men ought always to pray and not lose heart, supported by the parable of the persistent widow (Luke 18:2-5) and God's promise to avenge His elect who cry to Him (Luke 18:7-8).

questions.question: How does the parable of the Pharisee and the publican (Luke 18:9-14) teach us about humility in prayer?
options: Those who exalt themselves will be abased, and those who humble themselves will be exalted
Pride in prayer is a sign of righteousness
Publicans are more righteous than Pharisees by birth
Fasting twice a week guarantees justification
questions.correctAnswer: Those who exalt themselves will be abased, and those who humble themselves will be exalted
questions.explanation: Luke 18:14 clearly states that everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, but he who humbles himself will be exalted. The publican's humble confession contrasts the Pharisee's self-righteous prayer (Luke 18:11-13).

questions.question: What does Luke 18:15-17 teach about the attitude we should have to enter the kingdom of God?
options: Receive the kingdom of God as a little child
Earn the kingdom through works
Only adults may enter the kingdom
Children need to be silent around Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Receive the kingdom of God as a little child
questions.explanation: Jesus calls children to Him and teaches that only those who receive the kingdom like a little child will enter it (Luke 18:16-17), emphasizing humility, trust, and simplicity.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with contentment and possessions. Based on Luke 18:18-25, what guidance does Jesus give about riches and eternal life?
options: It is hard for the rich to enter the kingdom of God
Riches guarantee God's favor
One should keep all possessions for security
Selling possessions is not necessary for eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: It is hard for the rich to enter the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches that it is difficult for the rich to enter God's kingdom (Luke 18:24) and uses the metaphor of a camel going through a needle's eye (Luke 18:25). He advises selling possessions and giving to the poor to have treasure in heaven (Luke 18:22).

questions.question: How does Luke 18:26-27 encourage believers facing seemingly impossible challenges in their spiritual journey?
options: What is impossible with men is possible with God
Salvation depends on human effort alone
Only the wealthy can be saved
Difficulty means God has abandoned you
questions.correctAnswer: What is impossible with men is possible with God
questions.explanation: Jesus assures that while salvation and certain challenges may seem impossible for humans, they are possible with God (Luke 18:27), encouraging trust and faith in God's power.

questions.question: What promise does Jesus give to those who leave family and possessions for the kingdom of God's sake, according to Luke 18:28-30?
options: They will receive manifold blessings in this life and eternal life in the world to come
They will lose everything permanently
They will face no hardships
They must return to their families immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They will receive manifold blessings in this life and eternal life in the world to come
questions.explanation: Jesus promises that those who leave house, family, or possessions for His kingdom will receive many times more blessings now and eternal life later (Luke 18:29-30), encouraging faithful discipleship.

questions.question: Based on Luke 18:31-34, what attitude should believers have when facing God's plans, even if they do not fully understand them?
options: Trust in God's sovereign plan despite a lack of full understanding
Demand full explanation before following Jesus
Reject difficult circumstances as ungodly
Ignore prophetic warnings
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's sovereign plan despite a lack of full understanding
questions.explanation: Though the disciples did not understand Jesus’ predictions of suffering and resurrection (Luke 18:34), believers are called to trust God's plan as it unfolds (Luke 18:31-33).

questions.question: When a blind man calls out to Jesus for mercy (Luke 18:35-39), what does his persistence teach us about approaching God in prayer?
options: Persistent faith in prayer is essential, even amid rebuke
Silence is the best approach to prayer
Only the religious elite should pray
Prayer should be loud and disruptive
questions.correctAnswer: Persistent faith in prayer is essential, even amid rebuke
questions.explanation: The blind man cried out persistently despite being rebuked (Luke 18:39), demonstrating the value of steadfast faith and boldness in approaching God.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the blind man’s faith and its effect, in Luke 18:42-43?
options: Thy faith hath saved thee, and he immediately received sight
Faith is irrelevant to healing
Only Jesus’ power heals, not faith
The man was healed because of his wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Thy faith hath saved thee, and he immediately received sight
questions.explanation: Jesus attributes the blind man’s healing to his faith (Luke 18:42), showing the importance of faith in receiving God's blessings.

questions.question: How does Luke 18:20-21 emphasize the importance of obedience in daily living?
options: Keep the commandments from youth up
Commandments are optional for the righteous
Only some commandments matter
Obedience is irrelevant to faith
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the commandments from youth up
questions.explanation: The ruler claims to have kept the commandments since youth (Luke 18:21), emphasizing lifelong obedience as a foundation for righteousness (Luke 18:20).

questions.question: Based on the parable of the unjust judge (Luke 18:2-8), what principle about God’s justice and our persistence can be applied in trials?
options: God will bring justice speedily for those who persistently pray
God ignores persistent prayers
Justice depends on human effort alone
Only the righteous receive justice
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring justice speedily for those who persistently pray
questions.explanation: The parable teaches that if even an unjust judge grants justice due to persistence (Luke 18:5), how much more will God avenge His elect quickly (Luke 18:7-8).

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 18:22-23, Jesus told the rich ruler to sell all his possessions and give to the poor to have treasure in heaven.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jesus explicitly instructs the rich ruler to sell all he has and give to the poor to gain treasure in heaven and follow Him (Luke 18:22-23).

questions.question: True or False: Jesus rebuked those who brought infants to Him and told them to stop, according to Luke 18:15-16.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus rebuked His disciples, not the people bringing infants, and told them to allow children to come to Him, emphasizing their importance in the kingdom (Luke 18:15-16).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Luke 18:11-12, the Pharisee prayed, "God, I thank thee, that I am not as other men are, extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even as this _______."
options: publican
tax collector
sinner
Pharisee
questions.correctAnswer: publican
questions.explanation: The Pharisee compared himself to the publican (tax collector), whom he considered sinful (Luke 18:11).

questions.question: What does the response of the crowd to the healed blind man (Luke 18:43) teach about glorifying God in community?
options: The people praised God when they saw the miracle
The crowd ignored the miracle
People blamed the man for his blindness
The healed man left without testimony
questions.correctAnswer: The people praised God when they saw the miracle
questions.explanation: After the blind man was healed and followed Jesus glorifying God, the crowd also praised God, highlighting the communal aspect of worship and testimony (Luke 18:43).

hard.title: Luke Chapter 18 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Luke Chapter 18.

questions.question: What is the primary teaching of the parable about the unjust judge in Luke 18:1-8?
options: Men ought always to pray and not faint
God will delay justice indefinitely
Faith is unnecessary for salvation
Righteousness comes through works alone
questions.correctAnswer: Men ought always to pray and not faint
questions.explanation: Luke 18:1 states that Jesus spoke the parable so that men ought always to pray and not lose heart, emphasizing persistence in prayer.

questions.question: In the parable of the unjust judge, what motivates the judge to grant the widow's request?
options: Because she wore him out with her continual coming
Because he feared God
Because he regarded the widow's social status
Because the adversary was guilty
questions.correctAnswer: Because she wore him out with her continual coming
questions.explanation: Luke 18:5 explains that the judge grants the widow justice because her continual coming would weary him, showing persistence rather than righteousness motivates him.

questions.question: How does Luke 18:8 challenge the audience regarding faith?
options: It questions if the Son of Man will find faith on the earth when He comes
It assures that faith will always be abundant
It states that faith is unnecessary for the elect
It promises immediate justice for all believers
questions.correctAnswer: It questions if the Son of Man will find faith on the earth when He comes
questions.explanation: Luke 18:8 ends the parable with a question about whether the Son of Man will find faith on earth, emphasizing the challenge of maintaining faith.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in the parable of the Pharisee and the publican in Luke 18:9-14?
options: Contrast between self-righteousness and humility
Allegory of the kingdom of God
Typology of Old Testament priests
Foreshadowing of Jesus' crucifixion
questions.correctAnswer: Contrast between self-righteousness and humility
questions.explanation: Luke 18:9-14 uses a stark contrast between the Pharisee’s pride and the publican’s humility to teach about justification before God.

questions.question: The publican's prayer in Luke 18:13 highlights which Greek word often translated as 'mercy'?
options: Eleos
Agape
Dikaiosyne
Charis
questions.correctAnswer: Eleos
questions.explanation: The publican prays 'God be merciful to me,' using the Greek word 'eleos,' which signifies mercy and compassion, emphasizing his plea for grace (Luke 18:13).

questions.question: What theological theme does Jesus emphasize by saying 'every one that exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted'?
options: God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble
Only the rich can enter the kingdom of God
Faith is earned by works
Prayer is unnecessary for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble
questions.explanation: Luke 18:14 teaches the biblical theme of humility exalted by God and pride being brought low, consistent with Proverbs and other Scripture passages.

questions.question: In Luke 18:15-17, Jesus uses children to illustrate what essential quality for entering the kingdom of God?
options: Receiving the kingdom as a little child
Performing miracles
Strict adherence to the law
Accumulating wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Receiving the kingdom as a little child
questions.explanation: Jesus emphasizes in Luke 18:17 that entering the kingdom requires a childlike reception, symbolizing humility, dependence, and innocence.

questions.question: When the ruler asks Jesus what to do to inherit eternal life (Luke 18:18-21), how does Jesus initially respond?
options: By questioning why the ruler calls Him good
By commanding immediate sacrifice
By ignoring the question
By telling a parable about riches
questions.correctAnswer: By questioning why the ruler calls Him good
questions.explanation: Luke 18:19 records Jesus asking why the ruler calls Him good, emphasizing that only God is truly good, highlighting divine identity and authority.

questions.question: The command to sell all possessions and give to the poor in Luke 18:22 serves as an example of what broader New Testament teaching?
options: Detachment from material wealth to follow Christ
Legalistic observance of the law
Prosperity gospel promises
Avoiding taxation
questions.correctAnswer: Detachment from material wealth to follow Christ
questions.explanation: Jesus’ instruction in Luke 18:22 illustrates the call to renounce wealth as a barrier to discipleship, consistent with teachings on treasures in heaven.

questions.question: The metaphor of a camel going through the eye of a needle in Luke 18:25 symbolizes what in the cultural and historical context?
options: The extreme difficulty for the rich to enter God's kingdom
A common trade practice in Jerusalem
A type of needle used in temple rituals
An allegory for God's grace available to all
questions.correctAnswer: The extreme difficulty for the rich to enter God's kingdom
questions.explanation: Luke 18:25 uses hyperbole rooted in Near Eastern imagery to emphasize the near impossibility for the rich to enter the kingdom without divine intervention.

questions.question: How does Peter's statement in Luke 18:28 reflect the concept of discipleship's cost in the broader Gospel narrative?
options: He acknowledges having left everything to follow Jesus
He claims to have wealth and status
He denies any personal sacrifice
He demands political power
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledges having left everything to follow Jesus
questions.explanation: Peter’s confession in Luke 18:28 aligns with the theme of costly discipleship requiring surrender of worldly attachments seen throughout the Gospels.

questions.question: What prophetic event does Jesus forecast in Luke 18:31-33?
options: His suffering, death, and resurrection
The destruction of the temple
The coming of the Holy Spirit
The end of the world
questions.correctAnswer: His suffering, death, and resurrection
questions.explanation: Jesus predicts His passion, death, and resurrection in Luke 18:31-33, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies about the Messiah.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 18:34, the disciples fully understood Jesus' predictions about His suffering at the time He spoke them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 18:34 states that the disciples did not understand the sayings and that the meaning was hidden from them.

questions.question: What title does the blind man near Jericho use to address Jesus in Luke 18:38 and 18:39, and what is its significance?
options: Son of David, signifying messianic expectation
Rabbi, indicating a teacher
Prophet, referencing Old Testament figures
King of Israel, denoting political authority
questions.correctAnswer: Son of David, signifying messianic expectation
questions.explanation: The blind man calls Jesus 'Son of David' (Luke 18:38-39), a messianic title linking Jesus to Davidic lineage and Jewish hope for deliverance.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus' statement 'thy faith hath saved thee' to the blind man in Luke 18:42?
options: It highlights faith as the means of salvation and healing
It credits Jesus' power alone without faith
It implies a future salvation unrelated to sight
It emphasizes ritual purity
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights faith as the means of salvation and healing
questions.explanation: Luke 18:42 shows that the blind man's faith is the critical factor in his healing, linking physical and spiritual salvation.

theological.title: Luke Chapter 18 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Luke Chapter 18 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary teaching of the parable of the unjust judge in Luke 18:1-8 regarding prayer?
options: Men ought always to pray and not lose heart
Prayer is only effective when done publicly
God delays answering prayers to test faith
Only the righteous should pray
questions.correctAnswer: Men ought always to pray and not lose heart
questions.explanation: Luke 18:1 teaches that men ought always to pray and not faint. This aligns with teachings in 1 Thessalonians 5:17 (pray without ceasing), Romans 12:12 (continuing instant in prayer), James 5:16 (effective fervent prayer), Psalm 34:17 (God hears the righteous), and Jeremiah 29:12 (God listens to prayer).

questions.question: In the parable of the unjust judge, what motivates the judge to grant the widow's request?
options: Because the widow's continual coming weary him
Because he feared God
Because he respected the widow
Because the community demanded justice
questions.correctAnswer: Because the widow's continual coming weary him
questions.explanation: Luke 18:5 shows the judge grants the widow justice not out of righteousness but because her persistence troubles him. This contrasts God's nature who is just and compassionate (Psalm 9:7-8, Deuteronomy 32:4), always ready to avenge his elect (Luke 18:7), unlike the unjust judge.

questions.question: What question does Jesus pose at the end of the parable of the unjust judge regarding faith?
options: Will the Son of man find faith on the earth when He comes?
Should we pray only once?
Is it right to be persistent in prayer?
Will God delay His judgment forever?
questions.correctAnswer: Will the Son of man find faith on the earth when He comes?
questions.explanation: Luke 18:8 ends the parable with Jesus asking if He will find faith on earth when He returns, highlighting the importance of persistent faith. This connects with Hebrews 11:6 (faith pleases God), Matthew 24:13 (endurance in faith), Revelation 2:10 (faithfulness to death), and Romans 1:17 (the righteous live by faith).

questions.question: In the parable of the Pharisee and the publican, what is the key reason the publican is justified before God?
options: He humbly acknowledges himself as a sinner
He fasts twice a week
He gives tithes of all he possesses
He compares himself to others
questions.correctAnswer: He humbly acknowledges himself as a sinner
questions.explanation: Luke 18:13 shows the publican's humility and repentance, crying for mercy as a sinner, leading to justification (Luke 18:14). This reflects biblical teaching on justification by faith and humility (Romans 3:23-24, Isaiah 66:2, James 4:6, 1 Peter 5:5).

questions.question: According to Luke 18:14, what principle about humility and exaltation is taught?
options: Everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted
Only the wealthy will be exalted
Faith alone is sufficient for exaltation
Obedience to the law guarantees exaltation
questions.correctAnswer: Everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted
questions.explanation: Luke 18:14 teaches that humility before God leads to exaltation, a theme echoed in Proverbs 3:34, James 4:10, Matthew 23:12, and 1 Peter 5:6, emphasizing God's reversal of worldly values and the importance of humility in salvation.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the kingdom of God in relation to little children in Luke 18:16-17?
options: Whosoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a little child shall in no wise enter therein
Only adults can truly enter the kingdom
Children must first learn the law to enter the kingdom
The kingdom is reserved for the learned
questions.correctAnswer: Whosoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a little child shall in no wise enter therein
questions.explanation: Luke 18:17 emphasizes childlike receptivity and humility as prerequisites for entering God's kingdom. This is consistent with Matthew 19:14, Mark 10:15, Psalm 131:2, and 1 Corinthians 14:20, highlighting innocence and trust as spiritual qualities.

questions.question: When asked what he must do to inherit eternal life, how does Jesus first respond to the ruler's address of 'Good Master' in Luke 18:19?
options: He says no one is good except God alone
He affirms that he is good
He ignores the title
He asks why the ruler called him master
questions.correctAnswer: He says no one is good except God alone
questions.explanation: Luke 18:19 reveals Jesus' affirmation of God's unique goodness, teaching the ruler humility and the divine standard of goodness, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:4, Psalm 25:8, James 1:17, and Mark 10:18.

questions.question: What commandment does Jesus list to the ruler as essential for inheriting eternal life in Luke 18:20?
options: Do not commit adultery, do not kill, do not steal, do not bear false witness, honor your father and mother
Love your neighbor as yourself
Keep the Sabbath holy
Offer sacrifices regularly
questions.correctAnswer: Do not commit adultery, do not kill, do not steal, do not bear false witness, honor your father and mother
questions.explanation: Luke 18:20 lists commandments rooted in the Ten Commandments (Exodus 20:12-16), emphasizing moral and relational duties foundational for righteousness and eternal life, consistent with Romans 13:9 and Matthew 19:18-19.

questions.question: What does Jesus tell the rich ruler he lacks after he claims to have kept the commandments from his youth?
options: Sell all you have, give to the poor, and follow me
Offer a sacrifice to the temple
Pray more earnestly
Study the Scriptures daily
questions.correctAnswer: Sell all you have, give to the poor, and follow me
questions.explanation: Luke 18:22 commands the ruler to give up his riches and follow Christ, teaching the necessity of total surrender and trust in God for salvation, echoing themes in Matthew 19:21, Mark 10:21, Acts 2:44-45, and 1 Timothy 6:17-19.

questions.question: What teaching does Jesus give regarding the difficulty for the rich to enter the kingdom of God in Luke 18:24-25?
options: It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God
Rich people will have an advantage in the kingdom
Wealth guarantees salvation
Richness is irrelevant to salvation
questions.correctAnswer: It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Luke 18:25 uses hyperbole to illustrate how attachment to wealth hinders salvation, consistent with Matthew 19:24, Mark 10:25, 1 Timothy 6:9-10, and Proverbs 11:28, warning against idolatry of riches.

questions.question: How does Jesus respond when asked 'Who then can be saved?' in Luke 18:27?
options: The things impossible with men are possible with God
Only the perfect can be saved
We must keep the law perfectly
Salvation is only for the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: The things impossible with men are possible with God
questions.explanation: Luke 18:27 reveals God's omnipotence in salvation, affirming that human inability does not limit God's power to save, consistent with Ephesians 3:20, Jeremiah 32:17, Romans 8:31, and John 10:27-29.

questions.question: What promise does Jesus give to those who have left all for the kingdom of God's sake in Luke 18:29-30?
options: They will receive manifold more in this present time and life everlasting in the world to come
They will face eternal hardship without reward
They should expect to be forgotten by God
They will only receive rewards in heaven, not on earth
questions.correctAnswer: They will receive manifold more in this present time and life everlasting in the world to come
questions.explanation: Luke 18:29-30 promises abundant temporal and eternal blessings for sacrificial discipleship, echoing Matthew 19:29, Mark 10:29-30, Hebrews 11:6, and 2 Corinthians 4:17.

questions.question: What does Jesus predict about His own suffering and resurrection in Luke 18:31-33?
options: He will be delivered to Gentiles, mocked, scourged, put to death, and rise again on the third day
He will conquer Rome by force
He will reign immediately as king without suffering
He will avoid death through divine intervention
questions.correctAnswer: He will be delivered to Gentiles, mocked, scourged, put to death, and rise again on the third day
questions.explanation: Luke 18:31-33 foretells Christ's passion and resurrection, fulfilling Messianic prophecy (Isaiah 53, Psalm 22), consistent with John 18-20, Acts 2:24, and 1 Corinthians 15:3-4.

questions.question: What is the reaction of the disciples to Jesus' prediction of His suffering and resurrection in Luke 18:34?
options: They did not understand and the saying was hidden from them
They rejoiced and fully comprehended
They immediately told the crowds
They began to doubt Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: They did not understand and the saying was hidden from them
questions.explanation: Luke 18:34 reveals the disciples' lack of understanding, which was common before Pentecost, consistent with Mark 9:32, John 12:16, Acts 1:6, and Psalm 78:2-4 illustrating gradual revelation.

questions.question: What is the blind man's response when he hears that Jesus of Nazareth is passing by in Luke 18:38-39?
options: He cries out, 'Jesus, thou Son of David, have mercy on me!'
He remains silent and waits
He asks for money instead
He walks away disappointed
questions.correctAnswer: He cries out, 'Jesus, thou Son of David, have mercy on me!'
questions.explanation: Luke 18:38-39 shows the blind man's faith in Jesus as Messiah, calling Him 'Son of David' and pleading for mercy, consistent with Messianic recognition (Matthew 21:9, Psalm 22:16, Isaiah 35:5, John 9:38).
